newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - June 4.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - June 4.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Wednesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
BUSINESS DAY

- The Industrial Development Corporation (IDC) has sold some of its shares in Sasol to fund its $125 million investment in an aluminium smelter planned for Maputo, and would sell its remaining 10 percent stake in Sasol over the next three to five years.
- The financial markets were bullish on Tuesday, reflecting the surge in foreign exchange reserves, government's launch of a 40 billion yen samurai bond and lower money market interest rates.

- Tensions said to have developed last week, when some Saflife shareholders asked why mining house JCI had shed almost 30 percent of its share price since control effectively passed to black shareholders from Anglo American, were apparently eliminated on Tuesday.

- The Food and Allied Workers' Union (Fawu) one of SA's largest trade unions, is embroiled in a major internal battle with 11 national, regional and branch officials having either been suspended or removed from office in the past two months.

- Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe has given notice that the west and its economies will be targets rather than allies during his stewardship of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) over the next 12 months.
BUSINESS REPORT

- Plans by South African Breweries to introduce new products into Namibia have been thwarted by the Namibian government's refusal to grant a trading permit, Adriaan Botha, SAB's beer division spokesman, said on Tuesday.
- Wine cooperative KWV was being unnecessarily belligerent and provacative about negotiating the ownership of its assets, Derek Hanekom, the minister of agriculture, said on Tuesday.
- Anglo American reported a 23 percent rise in earninga for the year to March 31 as increases from diamond, gold and coal interests boosted profit to 5.015 billion rand, the group said on Tuesday.

- The retrenchment of up to 4,100 workers at the JCI-owned Randfontein Estates Gold Mine has been halted pending the outcome of discussions between the company and the National Union of Mineworkers, Gordon Miller, the general manager of the mine, said on Tuesday.
SAKE BEELD
- Tony Rowland, the chief executive of Lonrho, accuse Anglo American for hypocrisy in an advert that appeared in South Africa's financial press.
- Anglo American Corporation increased earnings per share 23 percent to 2,144 cents in the 12 months end March .
THE STAR
- South Africa's favourite tennis palyer, Amanda Coetzer, has done it again. On Monday, for the third time in four recent meetings, she toppled the worlds's No.2 player Steffi Graf.
- Starting revelations about the 185 million rand rural housing contract awarded to Motheo Construction were made at a sitting of Parliament's housing committee on Monday.
- Three passengers died when the bus they were travelling in collided with a truck and rolled at a busy intersection at Lenasia, south of Johannesburg, during peak-hour traffic on Monday afternoon.

- Johannesburg's southern council has lost about 60 million rand over the past two months because residents of Johannesburg's traditionally white southern suburbs have stopped paying for municipal services.
